cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hydraulic brake failure?
questions.explanation: Most cases of hydraulic brake failure come from one of two causes. The brakes may fail due to a loss of hydraulic pressure or due to overuse on long hills, causing the brakes to fade.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driverâ€™s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When backing a truck, always use the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Have someone help you whenever possible.

questions.question: To prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move, you can:
questions.answerA: Partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in second gear.
questions.answerC: Use the parking brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: To ensure that your vehicle does not roll backward when beginning to move after a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your right foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: What tells you how much pressure is in your vehicle's air tanks?
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Slow down and be extra careful:
questions.explanation: Slow down and be especially careful when driving in and around work zones, in places where the pavement drops off sharply at the edge of the road, when foreign objects are present on the road, and on freeway on- and off-ramps.

questions.question: Which of the following determines your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.explanation: The main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are how much alcohol has been consumed, how quickly it was consumed, and the person's body weight.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash down the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the other driverâ€™s behavior to police.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need eight to nine hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driverâ€™s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake pedal when the spring brakes are on. This could damage the brakes by subjecting them to the combined forces of springs and air pressure.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections are:
questions.answerB: Needed only for trips longer than 100 miles in length.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before every trip, regardless of length.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerC: Brake harder than you would with a different braking system.
questions.explanation: When braking a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should not brake any differently than you would if driving a vehicle with a different braking system.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesnâ€™t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: Your CDL will be revoked if:
questions.answerA: You want to add an endorsement.
questions.answerB: Your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked.
questions.answerC: You have not paid a toll.
questions.explanation: If your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended due to moving traffic violations, you will also lose your CDL. This does not apply if your license is revoked due to parking violations.

questions.question: What does an air compressor do in an air brake system?
questions.answerA: It pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: It moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerB: When driving at speeds slower than 15 mph.
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs on surfaces where water has collected. If there is enough water, vehicles can hydroplane at speeds as low as 30 mph. Hydroplaning becomes more likely if tires are under-inflated or if the tread is worn.

questions.question: If you are disqualified from driving:
questions.answerA: Your employer will be notified by the state.
questions.answerB: You must notify your employer within two business days.
questions.answerC: You must notify your employer within a month.
questions.explanation: You must notify your employer within two business days if your license is suspended, revoked, or canceled, or if you are otherwise disqualified from driving.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerB: Is essential to preventing cargo from moving in transit.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid loads.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate your brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get their attention.
questions.explanation: To let drivers behind you know that you plan to slow down, lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to flash your brake lights. It is important to communicate your intentions to other drivers.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should not light up or sound.
questions.answerB: Should turn on and shut off quickly.
questions.answerC: Should turn on and remain on.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers should turn on, then quickly turn off.

questions.question: To change lanes, you should:
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal when changing lanes.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When should a driver sign a vehicle inspection report?
questions.explanation: You must sign a vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and either certified to have been repaired or certified as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: When applying your brakes, the vehicle should:
questions.explanation: Your vehicle pulling to one side or the other while you are braking can indicate trouble with the brakes.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: While still below the legal limit, a driver operating a CMV with a detectable amount of alcohol in their system will:
questions.answerA: Result in an out-of-service order for two hours.
questions.answerB: Result in an out-of-service order for 10 hours.
questions.answerC: Result in an out-of-service order for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to have any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while operating a CMV but your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: Cargo should be covered:
questions.answerC: To make it more difficult to steal.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: Be sure that your wheel bearing/seals are:
questions.explanation: During an inspection, ensure that the wheel bearing/seals are not leaking.

questions.question: You should maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle when you are traveling more slowly than 40 mph.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: If a five-foot-long item is placed on a flatbed trailer, it must be secured by at least:
questions.explanation: Cargo that is required to be tied down should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo length. However, at least two tie-downs should be used no matter how small the cargo is.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Too much air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerC: A consistent name brand across all of your tires.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should verify that the air pressure is neither too low nor too high in any of your tires.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: A poor balance of weight in a trailer:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced weight in a trailer can make handling unsafe. For example, either too little or too much weight on the front axle can make a vehicle difficult to steer. Weight should be distributed evenly from front to back and from side to side. It should be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerB: Rely on the actions of other motorists to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Not rely solely on warning signals to indicate if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should not rely solely upon the presence of warning signals, gates, or flaggers to alert you to the approach of a train. Be especially alert to approaching trains at crossings that are not controlled by gates or signals. At any railroad crossing, you should operate under the assumption that a train is coming.

questions.question: When traveling in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerC: A speed much slower than the flow of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to match the speed of surrounding vehicles. Vehicles traveling in the same direction at the same speed are unlikely to collide. However, you should not exceed legal speed limits.

questions.question: When driving a 50-foot truck at 50 mph, your minimum following distance should be:
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. When traveling at higher speeds, follow the same formula, then add one additional second to your following distance.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: After two violations of any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use:
questions.answerA: You will need to cancel your mobile phone service.
questions.answerC: You will be required to drive 10 mph under the posted speed limit for a period of time.
questions.explanation: If you are twice convicted of violating any state law regarding hand-held mobile phone use, your CDL will be disqualified. Consequences will become more severe with subsequent violations.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it should be secured by a minimum of:
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: You are especially likely to encounter strong winds when:
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult to keep a vehicle in its proper lane. Strong wind can be a particular problem when a vehicle is being driven out of a tunnel.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: The center of gravity in a trailer should be:
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: The weight of cargo in a vehicle should be distributed as low as possible. Having a center of gravity that is too high will increase the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: If your license to operate a personal vehicle is revoked or suspended:
questions.answerA: You can get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerB: You cannot get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerC: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.explanation: If your license to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended, you may not obtain a hardship license to operate a CMV.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: When itâ€™s difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, a driver can increase their vehicle's visibility by:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must be:
questions.answerA: A U.S. citizen or permanent resident.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must be a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident. You will lose your hazardous materials endorsement if you renounce your U.S. citizenship.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop every ____ to take a break to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should stop to take a break at least once for every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: To prevent your vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move, you can:
questions.answerA: Partly engage the clutch before taking your foot off the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Place the vehicle in second gear.
questions.answerC: Use the parking brake when stopping.
questions.explanation: To ensure that your vehicle does not roll backward when beginning to move after a stop, you should partly engage the clutch before removing your right foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: In cool weather, as the temperature begins to rise and ice begins to melt:
questions.answerA: It is usually safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become even more slippery.
questions.explanation: As the temperature begins to rise and ice on the road begins to melt, the road surface will often become even more slippery. Water from the slight melting will sit on top of the ice, decreasing the available traction even more. Always decrease your speed and drive with caution when traveling on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: Containerized loads are used:
questions.answerA: When the cargo is too large to fit on a truck.
questions.answerB: When the cargo has been or will be transported by a train.
questions.answerC: When the cargo is a liquid.
questions.explanation: Containerized loads are generally used when freight is carried partway by rail or ship. Sealed materials cannot be inspected, but a driver should ensure that the containers do not exceed safe and legal weight limits.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driverâ€™s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: Brakes out of adjustment will:
questions.answerB: Cause some of the brakes to overwork and malfunction.
questions.explanation: Brakes out of adjustment will fade before those that are properly adjusted. Brake adjustment must be checked frequently to help prevent brake issues.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driverâ€™s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of a pre-trip inspection, seeing fresh oil underneath the vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle, you should check under the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks. Spotting any of these before a trip is a cause for concern.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes as firmly as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.explanation: Controlled braking is the method of applying a vehicle's brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels. A driver should keep steering wheel movements very small if braking while using this method.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see and you are traveling near other drivers, you should:
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when traveling near other drivers at times when it is difficult to see, such as at dawn, at dusk, or in poor weather conditions. Using the high beam setting under certain conditions could make it difficult for other drivers to see.

questions.question: When turning, when should the turn signal be canceled?
questions.explanation: Always signal continuously through a turn. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is finished.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: A safety valve is set to open at ____ pounds per square inch (psi).
questions.explanation: The safety valve protects air tanks and the rest of an air brake system from accumulating too much air pressure. The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi.

questions.question: After starting the engine, the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) light stays on if:
questions.answerB: The ABS is not working properly.
questions.explanation: The Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) indicator light should come on after an engine is started. The light will then turn off. If the light remains on, the ABS it not working properly.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: You are especially likely to encounter strong winds when:
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult to keep a vehicle in its proper lane. Strong wind can be a particular problem when a vehicle is being driven out of a tunnel.

questions.question: You should check and adjust your mirrors:
questions.explanation: Be sure to check your mirrors before beginning a drive. Your posture may change day to day and your mirrors may need to be adjusted.

questions.question: What does an air compressor do in an air brake system?
questions.answerA: It pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: It moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of tie-down equipment?
questions.explanation: You must use the proper number of tie-downs when securing cargo on a flatbed trailer. Examples of tie-down equipment includes ropes, straps, and chains.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driverâ€™s side is encouraged because:
questions.answerA: The driver will have the best possible view.
questions.answerB: Power lines should be on the passenger's side.
questions.answerC: Other drivers can offer assistance on the passenger's side.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, it is always recommended that a driver backs their vehicle toward its left side. This will allow the driver the best possible view of the rear of their vehicle.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, you will have to:
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, it may be necessary to leave the engine running when checking the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: What is the best way to stop if your brakes fail while you are driving downhill?
questions.answerB: Let the vehicle slow down on its own.
questions.answerC: Let rumble strips slow your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will need to quickly find something outside that can stop your vehicle. An escape ramp is the best option. If no escape ramp is available, use the least hazardous available option, such as driving into an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator in an air brake system:
questions.answerA: Makes the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevents ice from forming in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Lubricates parts of the braking system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems include an evaporator that introduces alcohol into the system. The alcohol can help prevent ice from forming within the system.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: A driver who stops at a green light could be:
questions.answerB: A driver who is color blind.
questions.answerC: A person who does not know the rules of the road.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they stop in inappropriate places, such as at green traffic lights.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: What is traction?
questions.answerA: Friction between the tires and road
questions.answerC: The length of time needed to activate the brakes
questions.explanation: Traction is friction between your tires and the surface of the road. Adequate traction is necessary for braking and steering.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: While driving, you:
questions.answerB: Can read text messages, but may not send any.
questions.answerC: Cannot hold a phone to make voice calls.
questions.explanation: While driving, you may not make voice calls if you need to hold your phone or press more than one button to do so. Additionally, you may not send or read text messages while driving.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
