questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Donâ€™t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: When starting from a complete stop, a vehicle should:
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting vehicles behind you, you must ensure that your vehicle will not roll backward when you start moving forward from a stopped position.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road.
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road.
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need eight to nine hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery when it first begins to rain because:
questions.answerB: The fresh rain mixes with oil on the roadway.
questions.answerC: The water has nowhere to go.
questions.explanation: Roads are particularly slippery when it first begins to rain. The water mixes with oil drippings on the road that have not yet washed away, creating a slippery and dangerous mixture.

questions.question: On a slippery road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make turns as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Under slippery conditions, you should drive slowly and smoothly. Make turns as gently as possible and do not pass other vehicles unless you have to.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Drivers must have a CDL if operating a vehicle designed to carry at least:
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license to operate a vehicle designed to seat 16 or more people, including the driver.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following items cannot be transported in the passenger compartment of a bus?
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in a space occupied by passengers.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a drawbridge with a green light:
questions.answerC: You must wait for the light to change to yellow.
questions.explanation: A bus does not need to stop before crossing a drawbridge controlled by a green signal light. The driver should still slow down and verify that it is safe before crossing.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Increase the amount of space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you. This reduces the need for you to make sudden changes in speed or direction while making it easier for the tailgater to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: When traveling on a downgrade, your vehicle will:
questions.answerB: Travel at the same rate as on level roadway.
questions.explanation: Gravity causes a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling on a downgrade. Adjust your speed before reaching a downgrade.

questions.question: While passengers are on board a bus, refueling the bus in an enclosed space, allowing the bus to be towed, and conversing with the passengers are considered to be:
questions.explanation: Bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers, fuel a bus inside an enclosed building, or tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle. These are all considered to be prohibited practices.

questions.question: Air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Are not allowed on a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Hold compressed air for the brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be drained of excess air after every trip.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold compressed air to be used by the brakes. The number and size of air tanks varies among vehicles.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: The rods in S-cam brakes move the slack adjusters when air pressure is added to the brake chambers. This air pressure is added to the chambers when the driver:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: Do not operate a vehicle if any brake drums have cracks that are larger than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: Once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi, the air compressor governor will:
questions.answerA: Stop the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerC: Begin pumping air into the tanks.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level around 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: What tells you how much pressure is in your vehicle's air tanks?
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal should activate:
questions.answerA: When tank pressure falls below 120 psi.
questions.answerB: When tank pressure falls below 60 psi.
questions.answerC: When tank pressure falls below 10 psi.
questions.answerD: When tank pressure falls below 5 psi.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, a low air pressure warning signal must come on if air pressure in the tanks falls below 60 psi. This warning signal may come in the form of a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in an air brake system is releasing air:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned as this is a normal process.
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: The safety relief valve in an air brake system releases air if necessary to prevent pressure in the system from becoming too high. If the valve starts releasing air, there is something wrong. Have a mechanic fix the problem.

questions.question: If air pressure drops to a level between ____, a visual low pressure warning signal should have already activated.
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: Operating combination vehicles usually requires Â­Â­Â­Â­Â­____ operating single vehicles.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), brakes should be applied:
questions.answerA: In the same way as they would be in a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: As the vehicle is placed in neutral.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same manner as you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: If you must cross traffic while driving a combination vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough for your vehicle to safely cross.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enonugh gap in traffic to safely do so.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the brake pedal harder than usual.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal as you normally would.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal more lightly than usual.
questions.explanation: When operating a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should apply your brakes in the same manner as you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: If an air supply control is in its "emergency" position:
questions.answerB: The trailer emergency brakes will be applied.
questions.answerC: The air supply to the trailer will increase.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: Look into the back of the fifth wheel:
questions.answerB: If your vehicle begins to skid.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: When testing ____, you should apply your vehicle's brakes with the hand control while moving the vehicle forward slowly.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: If a trailer begins to jackknife, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not apply the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerC: Can straighten the trailer with the parking brake.
questions.explanation: If a trailer begins to jackknife, you should release the brakes and allow the trailer wheels to regain traction with the road. Do not apply the trailer hand brake to attempt to straighten out the rig because the application of brakes is what caused the wheels to lock in the first place.

questions.question: Pushing in the trailer air supply control will:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has started to skid is by:
questions.answerB: Checking the trailer in your mirrors.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to jackknife is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: A trolley valve:
questions.answerB: Should only be used to test trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be used when parking uphill.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the trolley valve or Johnson bar) is a mechanism that works the trailer brakes. It should only be used to test the brakes. Using it while the vehicle is being driven could cause a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve will close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer will detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should not be used while you are driving because:
questions.answerA: It will disconnect from the vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will stop the vehicle too quickly.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: During a trip, landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. Landing gear that is not entirely raised could catch on railroad tracks or other hazards on the roadway.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance can present challenges when driving over:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Maintain a following distance of at least ____ for every 10 feet of your vehicle if you are traveling at a speed under 40 mph.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: During a trip, the ____ should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that it is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerB: A tractor attached to two trailers
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as bobtail tractors. Operating a bobtail tractor requires drivers to exercise caution.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second trailer, the trailer height should be ____ the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: Shut-off valves:
questions.answerA: Prevent air from escaping air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from entering air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Override vehicles that are out of control.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: The service air line is often controlled by the foot brake and is attached to the ____ valves.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downgrade.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place. Instead, use the parking brake or wheel chocks.

questions.question: Look into the back of the fifth wheel:
questions.answerB: If your vehicle begins to skid.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the cab and call for help.
questions.answerB: Exit the cab and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Motion for another driver to push your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: In an empty combination vehicle, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have:
questions.explanation: An empty combination vehicle will come to a complete stop more slowly than a fully-loaded vehicle. With less weight in a trailer, the stiff suspension springs and strong brakes will have lower traction than they would if the vehicle carried more weight.

questions.question: A trailer that is too high:
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: The ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over if a driver takes a turn too quickly.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: If you must cross traffic while driving a combination vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough for your vehicle to safely cross.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enonugh gap in traffic to safely do so.

questions.question: A driver should test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.
